content.notes: Content not refactored in Phase 1; original preserved under payload.

payload.posterTitle: South America: Sky Tablelands to the End of the World

biomes.name: Tepui Table Mountains
biomes.description: Tepuis are flat-topped mountains rising above the rainforest. Their sheer cliffs isolate summit worlds with unique plants and animals, and some launch towering waterfalls into the jungle below.

biomes.name: Cerrado Savanna
biomes.description: The Cerrado is Brazil’s great tropical savanna, shaped by drought and fire. Grasslands and twisted trees support wildlife like maned wolves, giant anteaters, and thousands of plant species.

biomes.name: Valdivian Rainforest
biomes.description: Chile’s Valdivian rainforest is cool, wet, and mossy. Ancient trees, ferns, and bamboo thickets create a dense green world with many species found only in southern South America.

biomes.name: Altiplano
biomes.description: The Altiplano is a high Andean plateau with thin air and big skies. Salt flats, volcanoes, and cold lakes create a harsh beauty where llamas and flamingos still find a way to live.

biomes.name: Yungas Cloud Forest
biomes.description: The Yungas are cloud forests on the eastern Andes. Warm air rises, cools, and turns to mist, feeding lush trees, orchids, and wildlife in a steep zone between mountains and lowland jungle.

biomes.name: Caatinga Dry Forest
biomes.description: The Caatinga is a seasonally dry forest in northeastern Brazil. Thorny shrubs, cacti, and tough trees survive long droughts, then burst into bloom when rains finally return.

biomes.name: Tierra del Fuego
biomes.description: Tierra del Fuego is a windswept land at South America’s tip. Cold forests, peat bogs, and rough coasts meet snow-dusted mountains, where storms and sea shape the landscape.
